title: Behavioral Interdependence
text:
The problem

Self-injury, self-harm, and suicide seem similar in principle
They are scientifically isolated in practice

title: Behavioral Interdependence
text:
How did we get here?

Maybe their similarities are only superficial
Focus on different populations led to bespoke theories
Lack of a sufficiently general model to unify them
Lack of sufficient model flexibility to accommodate their specific differences

title: Behavioral Interdependence
text:
Many organisms face interdependence

My best choice depends on how you are likely respond
Your best response then also depends on my next reaction

title: Behavioral Interdependence
text: Interdependence has predictable consequences

title: Behavioral Interdependence
section: Those predictable consequences are functionally equivalent across different groups and topographies of self-injury
text:
Those predictable consequences are functionally equivalent across different groups and topographies of self-injury

Namely, when other people experience your well-being as rewarding and/or your (self) harm as painful (personally costly), they will act to reduce your self-harm.
Because the experience of your self-harm is often so painful (and has social consequences) and others, they often react urgently (steep discounting)
This means there will often be a net incentive for someone to engage in self-harm

text:
Why is this new?

In some ways it’s not (PCIT, family therapy, suicide “gestures”)
It implies that other people are “first class citizens” in your pathology
Individually-focused interventions often ignore this, and leave it untreated
Pathological behavior is perhaps more rational than irrational
Novel treatment targets:

Environmental setups that
Other people’s attributes
Interactive equillibria

section: But I already do this in my therapy
text:
But I already do this in my therapy

Great, you’re a genius - will you please write some papers on your approach so that others can benefit from your substantial insight
But do you really? Or do you mean that your patient brings up other people and you have good (but general) social intuitions about ways those other people are important?
Okay, maybe you do, but not scientifically (because a systematic science of this stuff is rare in clinical psychology)

title: Behavioral Interdependence
text:
Some math
Imagine being in a state \(s1\), with two possible actions \(a_1\) and \(a_2\).

Utility

The utility of an action is a function, \(U(s, a)\) that takes states (\(s_1, s_2, ...\)) and (\(s_1, s_2, ...\)) returns a number from \(-\infty\) to \(+\infty\). All else equal, organisms choose actions with the highest expected utility for themselves.


\[
\begin{align}
U(a_1) &= 1.5 \\
U(a_2) &= 2.0 \\
U(a_1) &< U(a_2)
\end{align}
\]
